pull.title: test: fix floating point conversion in `wallet_encryption.py`
pull.body:
`time.time()` returns a floating point number and it is not being converted to int, causing the issue reported in https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/25758 in `wallet_encryption.py` test.

This PR proposes a fix, closes https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/25758 and https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/25482.

events.body:
```bash
test/functional/wallet_encryption.py:10:1: F401 'test_framework.util.assert_greater_than' imported but unused
^---- failure generated from lint-python.py
```
This was tracked for several months in https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/25021, which proposed a number of approaches.

> which proposed a number of approaches but was never merged.

The reason #25021 was never merged is outlined here: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/25021#issuecomment-1200207058. It had multiple unresolved review comments, and it was unclear if it was the correct fix, as it required modifying cpp code, unlike this change.

> unclear if it was the correct fix, as it required modifying cpp code, unlike this change.

It did not require modifying any cpp code. That was an optional tidy-up.
The point of my comment was to bring up discussion and tracking of the issue to help connect the dots.

<!--e57a25ab6845829454e8d69fc972939a-->

The following sections might be updated with supplementary metadata relevant to reviewers and maintainers.

<!--174a7506f384e20aa4161008e828411d-->
### Conflicts
Reviewers, this pull request conflicts with the following ones:

* [#25750](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/25750) (test: Temporarily work around Windows bug in walletpassphrase by MarcoFalke)

If you consider this pull request important, please also help to review the conflicting pull requests. Ideally, start with the one that should be merged first.

issue.title: test: Temporarily work around Windows bug in walletpassphrase
issue.body: The test passes on all platforms, such as freebsd, linux, or macos. However, it does not pass on Windows. Temporarily relax it on Windows to avoid wasting resources on manually triggered CI re-runs. The workaround can be reverted when the issue is understood and fixed.

events.body:
https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/25759#issuecomment-1200396590 addressed in https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/25759/commits/643675c4dfff6c0e174fd39e9a6ab10ed7681db5.

I didn't know about #25021. I'll take a look.

There is also #25750. None of the approaches fix the actual problem (which would require an explanation why it occurs / why it's windows-only/ideally steps to reproduce), but are workarounds relaxing the test assumptions in different ways so that the CI becomes green. I don't have an explanation either, but I think it is important to document that.
This is wrong. You'll have to replace `int`/`floor` with `ceil` as in Jon's pull or with `+1` as in my pull.
Also, it would be good to limit the workaround to only the platform that fails, including a reference/link for the workaround in the comment.
@MarcoFalke  Thanks for review. a5401b8  addresses the requested changes.

I think that implementing the requested changes will end up with code very similar to https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/25750. or https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/25021, so better continue the discussion in one of these PRs.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -79,18 +78,18 @@ def run_test(self):
         expected_time = int(time.time()) + MAX_VALUE - 600
         self.nodes[0].walletpassphrase(passphrase2, MAX_VALUE - 600)
         # give buffer for walletpassphrase, since it iterates over all encrypted keys
-        expected_time_with_buffer = time.time() + MAX_VALUE - 600
+        expected_time_with_buffer = int(time.time()) + MAX_VALUE - 600
comments.body:
This is wrong. From your linked bug report, `expected_time_with_buffer` is `...29.99` and `actual_time` is `...30`.

With `floor/int`, this will give `...29`, which will still fail the assertion.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -79,18 +78,18 @@ def run_test(self):
         expected_time = int(time.time()) + MAX_VALUE - 600
         self.nodes[0].walletpassphrase(passphrase2, MAX_VALUE - 600)
         # give buffer for walletpassphrase, since it iterates over all encrypted keys
-        expected_time_with_buffer = time.time() + MAX_VALUE - 600
+        expected_time_with_buffer = int(time.time()) + MAX_VALUE - 600

@@ -78,16 +80,27 @@ def run_test(self):
         MAX_VALUE = 100000000
         expected_time = int(time.time()) + MAX_VALUE - 600
         self.nodes[0].walletpassphrase(passphrase2, MAX_VALUE - 600)
-        # give buffer for walletpassphrase, since it iterates over all encrypted keys
-        expected_time_with_buffer = time.time() + MAX_VALUE - 600
+        # Calculate the expected timeout after the walletpassphrase call, since
+        # it iterates over all encrypted keys
+        if sys.platform == "win32":
+            # Temporarily work around Windows bug, see
+            # https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/25482
+            expected_time_with_buffer = math.ceil(time.time()) + MAX_VALUE - 600
comments.body: This is still wrong ceil(29.99) gives 30, which  fails the assertion below
